text: An appeal lodged by farmer Thomas Lane convicted of illegally felling trees in Gower has been dismissed. More than eight hectares of woodland were cut down - the equivalent of 12 football pitches in what was called a "devastating" loss of habitat https://t.co/3K2YTGORJ4

Terrifying footage shows the moment an explosion blew out windows during a flat fire started by a woman at her home. Sabina Khanom, 27, was jailed for arson after she set fire to her sofa at her Newport flat and tried to run back into the property https://t.co/uFIyvGDEjc

Cannabis dealer Lee Thomas was caught after his phone was seized by police and messages relating to drug dealing were discovered. He was said to have played a "significant role" and was expected to be making a steady profit https://t.co/EIKC5IHSBR

One of the most disturbing sentencings I've covered. Husband and wife David and Kim Crapper raped and sexually abused a young girl as she cried. They took advantage of her repeatedly and told police they were in love with the under aged girl https://t.co/cZ9SpEppJ3

"Our package of extra investment for barristers and solicitors, and measures such as unlimited sitting days and increasing magistrates’ sentencing powers, will help us to recover from the pandemic-induced backlog.”
A Ministry of Justice spokesperson said “Now that barristers have agreed to return to work we can work together to drive down the backlog and ensure victims see justice served sooner."
“If ministers cannot find the relatively small amount of money needed to help safeguard the future of the profession now, the justice system – and society – will pay the price for years to come.”

“Criminal defence solicitors are needed more than ever to help tackle these unprecedented backlogs in our criminal courts and yet government is still refusing to give them parity with barristers, on a 15% criminal legal aid rate rise, which would be the first increase in 25years"

“It is a disgrace that victims, witnesses and defendants are having to wait so long for justice. There is a grave risk that trust in our criminal justice system will continue to erode if the government doesn’t step up to address the endemic problems."

Law Society of England and Wales president Lubna Shuja said “The latest figures – which show an increase in the number of outstanding Crown Court cases and a concerning rise in the magistrates’ courts backlog – further demonstrate the dire state of our crisis-hit justice system."

Latest figures from HMCTS reveals there are 61,212 outstanding Crown court cases in Wales and England, rising from 60,351 in July. The number of outstanding magistrates' court cases stands at 360,611, up from 352,193 in July

RT @kirkkorner: The Crown Court backlog reached 61,212 in August, latest HMCTS figures show.

In a further blow to the UK Government, @TheLawSociety has said they will advise members "not to undertake" criminal defence work if the 15% increase for barristers is not extended to solicitors, who have been offered a 9% rate increase 3/3

The @MoJGovUK press release states the package includes £54m further investment in the criminal bar and solicitors and 15 percent fee increase, but some barristers say the headline figure "means nothing" 2/3
